list_definition.definition: an object which is supposed to have magic powers to protect its owner; a charm

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: He had a rabbit’s foot which he wore round his neck as a talisman.

list_ex_of_english: In our debates retrospectivity has become a kind of talisman, but the point can be overplayed.
He carries about with him, almost as a talisman, a letter from the industry thanking him for his services.
The factory-made watch is "a talisman" (559) and not a reification that conceals its embedded abstractions.
We wish to provide a talisman to guide those involved in promoting enjoyment of the parks.
In my view the price of bread has probably for far too long been the talisman by which the cost of living is measured.
It is most important to remember that science is not a talisman the magic effect of which can be turned on and off.
The road map is no magical talisman, but previous talks have also shown how close the two parties can become.
They are thinking that there is a kind of talisman, a kind of magic, in industrialisation.
